conclusion: To determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum, we need to analyze the relationship between acceleration, velocity, and time. The velocity of the object is obtained by integrating the acceleration over time. The velocity reaches its maximum when the acceleration becomes zero and starts to reverse direction (i.e., when the object stops accelerating positively and begins decelerating).
From \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 1 \), the acceleration is constant at \( 2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
From \( t = 1 \) to \( t = 2 \), the acceleration decreases linearly from \( 2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) to \( 0 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
From \( t = 2 \) to \( t = 3 \), the acceleration becomes negative and decreases linearly from \( 0 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) to \( -2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
From \( t = 3 \) to \( t = 4 \), the acceleration remains constant at \( -2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).

The velocity is the integral of acceleration over time: \( v(t) = \int a(t) \, dt \). The velocity increases when the acceleration is positive, and it decreases when the acceleration is negative. The velocity reaches its maximum when the acceleration becomes zero and transitions from positive to negative.

premise: From the graph, the acceleration \( a(t) \) becomes zero at \( t = 2 \).
conclusion: At \( t = 2 \), the velocity reaches its maximum because the acceleration transitions from positive to negative.

premise: From \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 2 \), the acceleration is positive, meaning the velocity is increasing.
conclusion: The velocity increases from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 2 \).

premise: At \( t = 2 \), the acceleration becomes zero, meaning the velocity stops increasing.
conclusion: The velocity stops increasing at \( t = 2 \).

premise: After \( t = 2 \), the acceleration becomes negative, meaning the velocity starts decreasing.
conclusion: The velocity starts decreasing after \( t = 2 \).

premise: The velocity increases from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 2 \), stops increasing at \( t = 2 \), and starts decreasing after \( t = 2 \).
conclusion: The velocity is at its maximum at \( t = 2 \).
